entry.title: keyboard freeze
entry.content:
Another potential fix to my keyboard freezing problem on Linux Mint 22.1 after going to sleep.

Edit Grub.

sudo vi /etc/default/grub

Add i8042.dubkdbd=1 to the GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT.

GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="usbcore.autosuspend=-1 quiet splash i8042.dumbkbd=1"

Update Grub and reboot.

sudo update-grub
reboot

Hopefully that fixes it.
entry.summary: Another potential fix to my keyboard freezing problem on Linux Mint 22.1 after going to sleep.

entry.title: disable usb autosuspend
entry.content:
I use a single keyboard between 2 computer systems (MacOS and Linux). I disconnect my USB keyboard on one system and plug it to another whenever I switch computers. When my keyboard is disconnected from Linux for a very long time, the system no longer recognizes the keyboard when I plugged it back in unless I reboot the system. After a little bit of a research, I found a potential solution to the issue. Essentially the fix is to disable the USB autosuspend option which will need to be added to grub.

Here are the steps:

sudo sed -i 's/GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="/&usbcore.autosuspend=-1 /' /etc/default/grub
sudo update-grub
sudo systemctl reboot

Hopefully it fixes the issue.

entry.title: comment multiple lines
entry.content:
How to comment multiple lines in nvim.

  1. Go to the first line you want to start to comment. Place cursor at the beginning.
  2. Enter Visual Block mode by pressing Ctrl+v.
  3. Use arrow keys or j to select multiple lines.
  4. Shift+I to enter insert mode.
  5. Choose a character (#) to use.
  6. Esc to comment multiple lines.
Ctrl+v
Use cursor or j
Shift+I
#
Esc

To uncomment

  1. Place cursor on the first comment.
  2. Enter Visual Block or Ctrl+v.
  3. Select columns using cursor or j,k.
  4. Press x or d to delete on selected lines.
Ctrl+v
Use cursor or j
x or d
entry.summary: How to comment multiple lines in nvim.

entry.title: copy paste nvim
entry.content:
How to copy and paste in vim or nvim.

Let’s say you have 10 rows of code that you want to copy somewhere else like at the bottom of your code.

  1. Press Esc to enter Normal mode.
  2. Move the cursor to the first line.
  3. Enter Visual Line mode. Shift+V.
  4. Move cursor or letter j or k.
  5. Press y to yank the selected lines.
  6. Move the cursor to your target location.
  7. Press p to paste after the current line.
  8. Or P to paste before the current line.
Esc
Move cursor
Shift+V
Move cursor
y
Move cursor
p or P
u

If you want to undo, press u.
entry.summary: How to copy and paste in vim or nvim.

entry.title: run node anywhere
entry.content:
Run your node script from anywhere by switching to a specific directory by changing to a working directory.

Place this code at the top of your node script.

#!/usr/bin/env node 

process.chdir('/absolute/path/to/your/directory');
console.log('Now running in:', process.cwd());

In addition, you can also add your node directory to your PATH so you can run it anywhere.

export PATH=$PATH:/absolute/path/to/your/directory

If you want it to be more permanent, add the export command to your ~/.bashrc in Linux or ~/.zshrc on a Mac.
entry.summary: Run your node script from anywhere by switching to a specific directory by changing to a working directory.

entry.title: feeding the starter
entry.content:
Feeding the sourdough starter (the beast).

  1. Take out 80% of the starter and throw it away or use it on other breads.

  2. Add 50 grams of flour to the starter.

  3. Add 50 grams of filtered water to the starter.

  4. Mix it thoroughly for 30 seconds or so.

  5. Place in the fridge until the next feeding or use.

  6. Feed your starter at least once a week.
